conclusion: Determine the kinetic energy of the second particle with mass 2m and charge q when it leaves the velocity selector N.
In the velocity selector N, the magnitude of the electric force must equal the magnetic force for the particle to pass through in a straight line.
The condition for straight-line passage is qE = qvB, leading to v = E/B.
The first particle has mass m and charge q.
The kinetic energy of the first particle is E_k = (1/2)mv^2, which simplifies to E_k = mE^2/(2B^2).
The second particle has mass 2m and charge q.
The second particle deviates from the dashed line, indicating unbalanced forces.
The vertical component of velocity due to magnetic force is v_y = qB/(2m).
The horizontal component of velocity due to electric force is v_x = qE/(2m).
The total velocity is v = sqrt((qE/(2m))^2 + (qB/(2m))^2) = (q/(2m)) sqrt(E^2 + B^2).
The kinetic energy of the second particle is E_k = (1/2) * 2m * ((q/(2m)) sqrt(E^2 + B^2))^2 = (q^2/(4m)) (E^2 + B^2).
Since the deviation is caused by unbalanced forces and the path is curved, the effective velocity is the same as the first particle.
The kinetic energy of the second particle is E_k = mE^2/(2B^2).
The kinetic energy of the second particle when it leaves the velocity selector N is mE^2/(2B^2).
